text: SAM 'ACE' ROTHSTEIN, a tall, lean, immaculately dressed m approaches his car, opens the door, and gets inside to tu on the ignition.

When you love someone, you've gotta  trust them. There's no other way.  You've got to give them the key to  everything that's yours.  Otherwise,  what's the point? And, for a while...  I believed that's the kind of love I  had. Suddenly, the car explodes. Flames, smoke and metal rise  into the sky covering the view of the Las Vegas casinos a their signs. Music in: J.S. Bach - 'St Matthew Passion'. Ace's body comes flying in - extreme slow motion. His bod twists and turns through the frame like a soul about to t into the flames of damnation. MAIN TITLE SEQUENCE.
Vignette of ACE through rippling flames, we move in on AC ROTHSTEIN overseeing the casino. He lights a cigarette.

Before I ever ran a casino or got  myself blown up, Ace Rothstein was a  hell of a handicapper, I can tell  you that. I was so good, that whenever  I bet, I could change the odds for  every bookmaker in the country. I'm  serious. I had it down so cold that  I was given paradise on earth. I was  given one of the biggest casinos in  Las Vegas to run, the Tangiers...

location: SAN MARINO ITALIAN GROCERY/BACK ROOM, KANSAS CITY

text: Vignette of MOB BOSSES sitting at a table surrounded by f and wine like the gods of Olympus.
...by the only kind of guys that can  actually get you that kind of money:  sixty-two million, seven-hundred  thousand dollars. I don't know all  the details.
Matter of fact...
Vignette of NICKY SANTORO standing at a bar with DOMINICK SANTORO, his brother, and FRANK MARINO, his right-hand ma
...nobody knew all the details, but  it should'a been perfect. I mean, he  had me, Nicky Santoro, his best  friend, watching his ass...
Vignette of GINGER MCKENNA a dazzling thirty-one-year-old blonde seated by a small fiery pool.
...and he had Ginger, the woman he  loved, on his arm.  But in the end...
ACE looks over the casino he rules.
...we fucked it all up. It should'a  been so sweet, too.  But it turned  out to be the last time that street  guys like us were ever given anything  that fuckin' valuable again.
Aerial shot coming down out of the clouds over the bright lit Vegas Strip and off into the blackness of the desert  night.

At that time, Vegas was a place where  millions of suckers flew in every  year on their own nickel, and left  behind about a billion dollars. But  at night, you couldn't see the desert  that surrounds Las Vegas...
Aerial shot swooping along the desert floor, then rising  above the mist to reveal mountains in the distance.
But it's in the desert where lots of  the town's problems are solved.

Got a lot of holes in the desert,  and a lot of problems are buried in  those holes. Except you gotta do it  right. I mean, you gotta have the  hole already dug before you show up  with a package in the trunk.   Otherwise you're talkin' about a  half-hour or forty-five minutes of  diggin'. And who knows who's gonna  be comin' along in that time? Before  you know it, you gotta dig a few  more holes. You could be there all  fuckin' night.
ACE is greeted by a casino exec and walked through the  brightly lit entrance to the Tangiers Casino.

Who could resist? Anywhere else in  the country, I was a bookie, a  gambler, always lookin' over my  shoulder, hassled by cops, day and  night. But here, I'm 'Mr Sam  Rothstein'. I'm not only legitimate,  but running a casino. And that's  like selling dreams for cash.

We see ACE enter alone. He is greeted by BILLY SHERBERT.  They are joined by top executives RICHIE and RONNIE in su and ties. They walk through the casino, past crowded and  noisy craps tables, spinning roulette wheels, blackjack  tables, poker-faced players at poker tables, and elegant, cordoned-off, black-tie, baccarat tables.
I hired an old casino pal, Billy  Sherbert, as my manager and I went  to work.
(Introducing the EXECS  to ACE) ...And this is Ronnie, who takes  care of the card room...
For guys like me, Las Vegas washes  away your sins. It's a morality car  wash. It does for us what Lourdes  does for humpbacks and cripples.  And, along with making us legit...

Dolly back from a wall of money. An employee pours a buck full of coins into a trough. Camera follows progress as  numerous coins move on a conveyor system, through a sorti machine. Camera reveals several rolls of coins on a lower conveyor as they move up a ladder towards an employee's h who then places the rolls on a rack.

...comes cash. Tons of it. I mean,  what do you think we're doing out  here in the middle of the desert?   It's all this money. This is the end  result of all the bright lights and  the comped trips, of all the champagne  and free hotel suites, and all the  broads and all the booze. It's all  been arranged just for us to get  your money. That's the truth about  Las Vegas.

Camera follows JOHN NANCE carrying a small suitcase and  walking through the casino to a door leading to the cashi cage. The sign on the door reads 'Authorized Personnel On He walks through the cage, to another door: 'Notice - Kee Out'.

We're the only winners. The players  don't stand a chance. And their cash  flows from the tables to our boxes  ...through the cage and into the  most sacred room in the casino ...the  place where they add up all the money  ...the holy of holies ...the count  room. He opens the door. We see inside the count room from NANC point of view. It looks like the area behind a teller's cage in a bank. large room, windowless, decor-free. One side is a mesh ca opened to reveal stacks of cash boxes. Several COUNTERS i white shirts are gathered around a glass table counting a sorting paper money.)
Now this place was off limits.
Verify two thousand.
Even I couldn't get inside, but it  was my job to keep it filled with  cash. That's for sure.

They had so much fuckin' money in  there, you could build a house out  of stacks of $100 bills. And the  best part was that upstairs, the  board of directors didn't know what  the fuck was going on. At one end of the room the clerks empty the metal boxes a rapidly count the cash at a counting table. The camera fo a cash 'drop box' being lifted from the stack by a clerk. pours the cash on to the table and shows the empty box to video camera. COUNTER #2 rapidly counts the cash and  announces:
Five thousand.
I mean, to them everything looked on  the up and up. Right? Wrong. The first counter recounts the cash.
Verify five thousand.

The guys inside the counting room... Stacks of bills lie nearby. The camera pans across the ro to another table manned by a COUNT ROOM EXECUTIVE who rep the figure and writes it down on a master list.

Five thousand. We move back to NANCE opening a cabinet full of stacks of $100 bills. He opens his suitcase and begins to fill it w cash. As he does this, the workers studiously look in oth directions.

...were all slipped in there to skim  the joint dry.  They'd do short  counts, they'd lose fill slips. They'd  even take cash right out of the drop  boxes. And it was up to this guy  right here [NANCE], standin' in front  of about two million dollars, to  skim the cash off the top without  anybody gettin' wise ...the IRS or  anybody.
Verify two hundred. NANCE closes the case and walks out. One of the counters  dumps another container of money on the table.

Now, notice how in the count room  nobody ever seems to see anything.  Somehow, somebody's always lookin'  the other way. Now, look at these  guys [COUNTERS]. They look busy,  right?  They're countin' money. Who  wants to bother them? I mean, God  forbid they should make a mistake  and forget to steal. Meanwhile, you're  in and you're out. NANCE exits the count room and proceeds through the lobby the casino, passing ACE and SHERBERT, to a side exit door

Past the jag-off guard who gets an  extra c-note a week just to watch  the door.  I mean, it's routine.  Business as usual: in, out, hello,  goodbye. And that's all there is to  it. Just another fat fuck walkin'  out of the casino with a suitcase.  Now, that suitcase was goin' straight  to one place: right to Kansas City  ...which was as close to Las Vegas  as the Midwest bosses could go without  gettin' themselves arrested. NANCE leaves the casino and gets into a cab parked at the curb.
NANCE arrives. He is greeted by ARTIE PISCANO, a gray-hai sixty-year-old underboss.
That suitcase was all the bosses  ever wanted ...and they wanted it  every month.
Hey, John, how are you? How was your  ride?

location: SAN MARINO ITALIAN GROCERY, KANSAS CITY

text: NANCE, with suitcase, and PISCANO leave the car and enter the produce market.
Now this old Mormon fuck here...

location: SAN MARINO ITALIAN GROCERY, KANSAS CITY

text: NANCE and PISCANO walk through the grocery store, through the warehouse, past various employees to a doorway leadin into the back room, where they are greeted by five older around a large wooden table with bowls of macaroni and ol jelly glasses filled with red wine.
...he had to fly in with suitcases  once a month, nice and easy.
Somethin' smells good.
Yeah, they made us somethin' to eat.

The bosses would come from all over  the place: Detroit, Cleveland,  Milwaukee. All over the Midwest.   And they would meet in the back of  this produce market in Kansas City.  I mean, nobody even knew. NANCE shakes hands with AMERICO CAPELLI, sixty-eight, a b affable Milwaukee entrepreneur and ARTHUR CAPP, his thirt year-old yuppie lawyer son. Camera continues to pan around the room.
One of the guys made his mother do  all the cooking. On VINCENT BORELLI, seventy-year-old Kansas City boss.
Did you ever see that guy Jerry  Steriano? On VINNIE FORLANO, mid-seventies, an old-timer who once d for Capone and is now Remo Gaggi's right-hand man.
Jerry Steriano?
Yeah.
Now, these old greaseballs might not  look it, but believe me, these are  the guys who secretly controlled Las  Vegas. PISCANO joins his MOTHER and DAUGHTER by a stove.
That man's here again. Piscano dips a piece of bread into a pot of tomato sauce.
Because they controlled the Teamsters'  Union, and that's where you had to  go if you wanted to borrow money to  buy a casino.
When you've finished with him, I  want him.
(Carrying a plate of  food to the table  where BORELLI and  FORLANO are seated.) Here you are, gentlemen.
And nobody got a Teamsters' loan,  unless the guys in this room knew  they were gonna get their little  suitcases. FORLANO gets up from the table and walks toward NANCE.
Guys like this antique here [FORLANO],  out of Detroit. Or especially guys  like Remo Gaggi, the outfit's top  boss. NANCE embraces REMO GAGGI who's seated on a couch, and si across from him.
You got a round figure on it?
Definitely the most important guy in  this room.
(Picking up the  suitcase) About twenty pounds.
So?
That's around seven hundred thousand.
Uh-huh, good. NANCE opens the case to reveal the money.
(Off-screen, from  following scene) I know it's a little early for Las  Vegas...

location: TANGIERS EXECUTIVE OFFICE PRESS CONFERENCE/BANQUET R

text: Camera tilts down a model of the Tangiers Hotel and Casin then reveals the cover of Business Week magazine with a  drawing of PHILIP GREEN, a young corporate type, smiling under the headline: 'Philip Green, Vegas Wunderkind'.

...but I do want to welcome the ladies  and gentlemen of the gaming industry. On ANDY STONE, a middle-aged man at a podium giving a spe while GREEN, seated at a table, looks on. PHOTOGRAPHERS f their cameras. ACE and SHERBERT, sitting next to GREEN, a watch the photo op ceremony.
As far as the world was concerned  Andy Stone, the head of the Teamsters'  Pension Fund, was a legitimate guy.
This is a very auspicious occasion.
A powerful man.
Philip, if you would rise. Green stands up.
He even played golf with the  President.
On behalf of the Teamsters' Pension  Fund, it is my pleasure to present  to you . . .
But Andy also took orders. And when  he was told to give a pension fund  loan to Philip Green...
(Handing GREEN a large  cardboard facsimile  'check') ...this check for $62,700,000 for  the new Tangiers.
Thank you.
...he did what he was told. PHILIP GREEN, who is now the head of the Tangiers Hotel a Casino Corporation, is standing at the podium giving a sp

Now here was the perfect front man.  I mean, what the fuck else could he  be?  He didn't know too much. He  didn't want to know too much,  especially that the bosses made the  Teamsters lend him the money. He  wanted to believe the Teamsters gave  him all that fuckin' money 'cause he  was smart. An exploding flash bulb fills the screen.
...I say that, knowing full well  just how much competition we have in  this great city.

We see a MAN and a WOMAN swimming underwater. Camera reve that they are in a motel swimming pool with glass porthol Expensive cars are parked outside one of the rooms. Hoods stand around outside the door.
And where they got Green from - who  the fuck knows?  All I know is that  Green was an Arizona real estate  hustler, who barely had enough gas  money to come and pick up his own  fuckin' check...

location: TANGIERS EXECUTIVE OFFICE PRESS CONFERENCE/BANQUET R

text: We return to the press conference. Photographers snap awa In the background are six-foot blow-ups of the Business W cover. The camera moves past GREEN, CAPP and several othe men, past SHERBERT, to ACE.

Now, all they needed was somebody  they could trust to run the casino.  And who better than Ace?  I mean, he  was already in Vegas a couple of  years and he had the fuckin' place  clocked. FREEZE FRAME ON ACE.
Camera looks straight down from the top of a hotel to a l pool area.
But typical Ace...
STONE, in a bathing suit and robe, sits on a lounge chair with a telephone. ACE, in sports clothes, sits on another chair.
...give him a shot at runnin' a casino  and he tries to talk you out of it.
You know, I don't know if I could do  this even if I wanted to. The Gaming  Commission would never give me a  license. I have at least two dozen  gambling and bookmaking pinches on  me.

You don't have to have a license to  work in a casino. All you gotta do  is apply for one. The state law says  you can work in a casino while they're  processing your application. They  got a ten-year backlog.
But what happens when they do find  out?

Why would they want to find out?  We're puttin' a hundred million into  this desert here. Why would they  want to lock us out?  And besides,  they'll never find out. All you gotta  do is keep changing your job title.  Like, uh, from Casino Executive to  Food and Beverage Chairman. And what  happens it, they take your  application, they put it at the bottom  of the pile. I know guys workin'  there for thirty years, don't have a  license.
(Exhales) It's a tough proposition, Andy. You,  you know, if I did it, I'd have to  run it my way.
You got it.
I'm serious. No interference.
Nobody's gonna interfere with your  running the casino. I guarantee it. Stone lights a cigarette.
ACE blows on a die.
And that's how that got Ace to take  over. ACES's hands place the die into a micrometer.
They wanted him because Ace ate,  slept and breathed gambling. Camera swish tilts up to ACE, then swish pans to boxman,  dealers and players watching him, trying to act calm.
They worked out a real cute job title  too. We see the die in the micrometer.
Tangiers Public Relations Director. Satisfied the die is not loaded ACE sets it on the craps  table, the camera cranes up to reveal the Tangiers Casino floor.

But the only thing he ever directed  was the casino. He made his first  bet when he was fifteen years old,  and he always made money. But he  didn't bet like you or me. A DEALER is sliding chips, tossing them on to a craps tab
You know, havin' some fun with it,  shit like that.
(Approaching the DEALER) Where the hell did you learn how to  deal? (He reaches down,  stacking and arranging  the chips.)
He bet like a fuckin' brain surgeon.
(To the chastised
Place the checks properly. That's  the way you do it.
Yes, sir.
He had to know everything, this guy. Direct overhead tracking shot as ACE walks between two ro of gaming tables.
He'd find out the kind of inside  stuff nobody else knew, and that's  what he'd put his money on.
ACE walks past two boxers sparring in a ring, through a  doorway into a room where several gamblers are seated aro a table.
Even back home, years ago, when we  were first hangin' out together...
...he'd know if the quarterback was  on coke. ACE is looking at the odds board for college football gam The bookie, LUCKY LARRY, is waiting for ACE to hand in hi picks.
I'll take Columbia for twenty.
If his girlfriend was knocked up.
Twenty dimes on Columbia . . . As soon as ACE bets, a man erases a number from the chalk and replaces it was a '6', changing the odds. Two GAMBLER saunter from the room.
He'd get the wind velocity so he  could judge the field goals. He even  figured out the different bounce you  got off the different kinds of wood  they used on college basketball  courts, you know?
The two GAMBLERS we saw sauntering out of the bookie join are racing to the nearest public phones. Another GAMBLER already beaten them to it.
He'd be workin' on this shit day and  night. There was nothin' about a  game he was gonna bet that he didn't  know.
(Into phone) Ace got down at six.
(Into phone) Charlie, hey. Rothstein got six.

head_text.subj: INT. GYM/BOOKIE JOINT, SEVERAL DAYS LATER

text: A bookie hands a stack of money to another bookie, who ha the money to ACE. ACE removes several bills from the top of the stack of  winnings and holds them out to the BOOKIES.
Season after season, the prick was  the only guaranteed winner I ever  knew. But he was so serious about it  all that I don't think he ever enjoyed  himself.  But... ACE exits.
...that's just the way he was.

The room has an espresso machine and a saint's day calend Assorted hoods are listening to NICKY at the bar. Camera  dollies to REMO GAGGI, at the rear table playing gin rumm with OLD MAN CAPO and losing. Every time the CAPO picks u card, he's able to knock or get gin, sending GAGGI into a fit bemoaning his bad luck.

But back then the bosses didn't give  a fuck about whether he enjoyed  himself of not. To them, he was a  cash register. All they had to do  was ring the bell and take the money.  Especially Remo, who was a fuckin'  degenerate gambler who always lost.
(Slams down his cards  and curses at his  losing hands) Ma che cazzo! [Italian-American slang for 'What a prick.'] All those fu sweeps.
I mean, unless Ace made his bet.
That's enough now!
I can't contest the cards.
Va fa 'n culo! [Italian-American  slang for 'Fuck off']  (Summoning a young  man.) Johnny!
Ace made more money for them on a  weekend than I could do heisting  joints for a month. ACE enters and walks to GAGGI's table.
Whatever Ace picked up on the street  he told Remo.
(Walks over to ACE  and whispers) Hey, did you bring that thing?

You know, I mean fixed fights, doped  horses, crooked fuckin' zebras...  locked-in point spreads. He told  fuckin' Remo everything. And to tell  you the truth. I don't blame him. GAGGI stands up and shakes ACE's hand.
Ace.

Keepin' Remo happy with money was  the greatest insurance policy in the  world. GAGGI beams as ACE takes out an envelope filled with cash and hands it over to him. GAGGI sits back down and ACE,  knowing his place, smiles and is about to leave.
Son-of-a-bitch. How the hell did you  get Oklahoma-Michigan?  Nobody ever  had Oklahoma-Mi... How the hell'd  you do it?
Well, that's why they paid so well.
You see? (Chuckles.) Never tells me nothin'. Ace, what do  we got on for next week?
Well, it's a little too early. I'd  say Thursday would be good. I'll  know by then. Is that all right?
Okay. You come by the house?
I'll come by.
Seven o'clock?
Seven o'clock. GAGGI gets up and kisses ACE as NICKY and OLD MAN CAPO lo on.
Good job, my boy. Keep it up. Okay,  Ace? ACE nods in agreement and leaves the room.
(To NICKY) Hey, Nick. Vien acca. [Italian- American slang for 'Come here']
(To ACE) I'll be right out.
T'aggia parla. [Italian-American  slang for 'I've got to talk to you']  Nicky... See that guy? (pointing to the off- screen ACE)
Mm.
Keep a good eye on him. He's makin'  a lot of money for us. And he's gonna  continue makin' a lot of money for  us, so keep a good eye on him.
Mm.
Not like your fuckin' friends out  there, that... without brains.  Okay?
All right.
Uh-huh. Mi raccomando. [Italian- American slang for 'I'm counting on  you']
Yeah.
Fine.
(Reaching down to  touch GAGGI's money,  joking with him.) Want me to take this for you? (He walks out.)
So, now, on top of everything else,  I gotta make sure that nobody fucks  around with the Golden Jew.
We move past JOE, a guy at the bar entertaining a BRUNETT and a BLONDE, to NICKY and FRANK MARINO at the other end. There are other bar patrons in the background.
(To the BARTENDER) Chase, couple of shooters for the  ladies.
All right.
Yeah, we made a great pair. I made  book and Nicky made sure we always  collected. The old men loved us. And  why not? They all made money with  us.
(To MARINO) They payin'?
How did Nicky collect?
They pay every week, like they're  supposed to.
Don't ask.
Then where the fuck is the money? I  don't see the money. ACE enters, and greets the two girls.
Hi, Melissa. Heidi.
Hi, Sam.
(To the GIRLS) Who's this guy?
(To NICKY) Get the fuck out of here. It was  nine. I laid nine. ACE approaches NICKY and MARINO.
It was eight.  Ace... tell him the  line on the Bear's game.
Eight.
If he don't know, nobody knows. Told  you it was eight.
Well, how come I laid nine?
'Cause you're a jag-off. I would  have fuckin' made you lay ten... ACE notices a pen lying on the bar. He taps JOE on the  shoulder.
(To JOE) Excuse me.
What?
(He holds up the pen) Is this yours? Your pen?
Yeah, that's my pen. Why?
I ju- Well, it's a nice pen. I just  didn't know whose it was. I thought  it was yours. I didn't want it to  get lost.
Well, thank you. Why don't you take  that fuckin' pen and shove it up you  ass, you fuckin' jag-off? NICKY looks over.
Well, I was just offering you the- NICKY moves towards JOE.
(Turning his back to  talk to the girls,  referring to ACE) This fuckin' asshole. NICKY grabs the pen out of ACE's hand.
(To JOE) Look out! Before ACE can react, NICKY grabs JOE and starts stabbing him in the neck with the pen.

Joe! Look out, Joe! Look out! NICKY grunts while JOE gasps and groans. The BLONDE screa while NICKY's hand continues to plunge the pen into JOE's throat. JOE tumbles to the floor. NICKY pounces on him, still stabbing and now kicking. JOE whimpers.

What's that? You hear? You hear a  little girl, Frankie? You hear a  little girl, Ace? Is that a little  fuckin' girl?!  What happened to the  fuckin' tough guy?  Told my friend  stick it up his fuckin' ass?! Huh?!  Huh?!
(Over whimpers and  pants) Wait a sec, Nicky, Nicky, Nicky. Ta- take it easy. ACE looks stunned. NICKY's still holding the bloody pen.

While I was tryin' to figure out why  the guy was sayin' what he was sayin',  Nicky just hit him. No matter how  big a guy might be, Nicky would take  him on. You beat Nicky with fists,  he comes back with a bat. You beat  him with a knife, he comes back with  a gun. And you beat him with a gun,  you better kill him, because he'll  keep comin' back and back until one  of you is dead.
Listen...

Camera swoops from a woman cheering as she wins at a slot machine to a blackjack table, then to a roulette table an over to a craps table. Montage of very short cuts of chips being picked up, dice thrown, money being poured from a bucket, stacks of money

...with me protecting Ace, he made a  fortune for the bosses. I mean that's  what got him to Vegas. He was a money  machine. A tremendous earner for  these guys.  As soon as he took over,  he doubled the fuckin' drop. With  Ace the casino never saw so much  money. And the bosses, they couldn't  be happier.

Camera moves in on ACE as he looks out over the casino.  Dealers deftly stack chips, scoop up losses and pay off  winners. Chips and money are everywhere. In extreme close-up slow motion a die falls on to a table
ACE and SHERBERT are walking down a casino aisle by the s machines. Dealers immediately snap to attention at their  approach.
In Vegas, I had to keep a few juiced- in local cowboys working. They were  close to the, you know, good old  boys.
(To SHERBERT) Pay him six hundred a week, tell him  to walk around and look smart.

I mean, without us, these guys, they'd  still be shovellin' mule shit. ACE points at paper cups, empty glasses and the debris of silver dollar wrappings on the floor. DON WARD, the Slots Manager in Western garb, immediately starts picking up th debris. ACE looks at WARD sternly.
Ward, you gotta keep a cleaner  station. If you need 'Mr Clean',  page him, all right? WARD bends down and picks up some trash.
It won't happen again, Sam.
Mr Rothstein.
(To SHERBERT) Is this guy just another dumb fuckin'  white man, or what? What's his story?
We need this guy.
We can't get rid of him?
He's juiced in. He's the County  Commissioner's cousin.
I wouldn't give the bum a mop job. They exit.
A card shoe slides across the baccarat table. A state SEN a little drunk, tips the dealer, kisses the blonder HOOKE with him, fills his pockets with his winnings and walks o to see ACE.
These yokels ran the state.
Thank you very much, Senator.
They passed the laws, they owned the  courts.
Hi, Ace.
Hello, Senator. They shake hands.
(To ACE) Hey, I need a room. Need a room.
Good to see ya. (To SHERBERT) William would you... The SENATOR shakes hands with SHERBERT as the HOOKER join them.
I had dozens of politicians and state  officials comin' through that place  every week.
Nice to see you, Senator.
(To SHERBERT) Help the Senator, give him whatever  he wants.
Certainly. (Leads the way.) Senator.
Why not make them happy?
We have some nice penthouses you'll  enjoy. Maybe the Presidential Suite.
The SENATOR unzips the HOOKER's dress, kisses her and wal through the bedroom doorway, looking over his shoulder to her as she takes off her dress and walks out of his sight
For politicians...
ACE smoking a cigarette by the baccarat tables.
...like our state senator up there,  everything was on the house.
The SENATOR opens a bureau drawer and takes out a small v pouch and pours black $100 into his palm.
These guys won their comped life  when they got elected. So, hey, why  not take advantage of it? Still, the  politicians come cheap. We could  handle them.
K. K. ICHIKAWA a Japanese businessman, and a male associa pick up towels and soap from about the bedroom of their s A blonde woman checks herself in the mirror.

It's a whale like K. K. Ichikawa,  who plays thirty thousand dollars a  hand in baccarat. That's the one you  really gotta watch. ICHIKAWA and his associate walk into the the suite's livi room and join a Japanese woman seated on a couch.

He plays fast and big and he has the  cash and the credit to turn out your  lights. About a year ago, he cleaned  out a couple of casinos in the Cayman  Islands. They begin to stuff Tangiers soap and towels into their  luggage.
Downstairs, he takes us for two  million... and upstairs he takes  free soap, shampoo and towels. Another  billionaire cheapskate who loves his  free rooms...
The Tangiers jet with the Tangiers logo on its side as  ICHIKAWA shakes ACE's hands before boarding. SHERBERT fol him and his associates aboard.
...free private jets, and two million  of our money.
Nice to see you again.
But we got him back. I had our pilot  tell him the plane was on the fritz.

location: TANGIERS JET, STILL IN THE SAME SPOT

text: SHERBERT apologizes to ICHIKAWA and his entourage as they all get off the jet.
Ken, I don't know what the hell went  wrong. I'm awfully sorry.
This is a big problem. Big problem.
I can't understand it. These  mechanical things, you know, they  happen. Hey, be-better here than (gesturing to the sky) up there, you know what I mean?
SHERBERT arguing with TICKET AGENT as ICHIKAWA and entour look glum.
Then he missed the commercial flights  connecting with Japan.
I'm so sorry. There's a convention  in town, and all flights are booked.
A convention? (Turning to ICHIKAWA) I can't believe that there's a  convention. It's never... ?
What can I do?
A smiling ACE greets ICHIKAWA and his entourage as they d up and get out of Tangiers limos.
We got him back ...with a whole floor  of rooms for himself.
I'm sorry you missed the plane.
You want to get my money back, right? (Chuckles)
No, no, no. No gambling. No.
ICHIKAWA, with the Japanese woman, picks up some chips an places them on the table. ACE and SHERBERT watch from beh a barrier.
He bet one thousand a hand instead  of his usual thirty thousand a hand. A dealer's hands slide two cards on the table.
The bank wins a natural eight over a  five. Another dealer's hands place two chips on a table. ICHIKA looks on.

But I knew, the trick with whales  like Ichikawa was that they can't  bet small for long. He didn't think  of it as winning ten thousand, he  thought of it as losing ninety  thousand. ICHIKAWA places a larger bet.
So, he upped his bets... A dealer picks up some chips from a rack and places them the table. ICHIKAWA is now seated with stacks of chips in front of h
...until he dropped his winnings  back and gave up a million of his  own cash.
ICHIKAWA, hours later, his chips depleted. ACE and SHERBE still watch from behind the barrier as millions in chips back in the dealer's racks.
In the casino, the cardinal rule is  to keep them playing... Move in on ACE as he smokes a cigarette.
...and keep them coming back. The  longer they play, the more they lose.  In the end, we get it all.
ACE, with pit bosses next to him, looks out over the huge casino where hundreds of thousands of dollars are being p into machines.
In Vegas, everybody's gotta watch  everybody else. Camera reveals the DEALER at a craps table.
Six, an easy way. Six! All right,  who's gonna give me...  The DEALER places some chips on the table.
Since the players are looking to  beat the casino... THE CAMERA IS ON THE DEALER.
...both dice must hit that back wall  each and every roll. All right, make  a six!
...the dealers are watching the  players.
Gimme a six!
Come on, baby, make a six! A BOX MAN, seated mid-table is watching the DEALER.
The box men are watching the dealers. CAMERA PANS TO THE DEALER.
(Humming, fielding,  every roll.)
The floor men are watching the box  men.
The pit bosses are watching the floor  men. SWISH PAN TO A SHIFT BOSS SURVEYING THE CASINO.
The shift bosses are watching the  pit bosses. SWISH PAN TO SHERBERT.
The casino manager is watching the  shift bosses. SWISH PAN TO ACE.
I'm watching the casino manager.

head_text.subj: INSIDE A GLASS DOME HANGING FROM THE CEILING.

text: And the eye-in-the-sky is watching  us all.
Video monitors show a dealer fanning a row of bills. Swis pan to ACE and SHERBERT watching the monitor. ACE lights cigarette.
Plus...

head_text.subj: SPYING ON PLAYERS BELOW WITH BINOCULARS.

text: ...we had a dozen guys up there,  most of them ex-cheats, who knew  every trick in the house.
Ginger squeals as she throws the dice across the table.
Come on, come on. She rolls a winner.
Yes!
Thank you. Very nice.
(Chuckles) I told you I was hot tonight.

Sound out: The monitor shows GINGER and the HIGH ROLLER  cheering, she throws her arms around him. The crowd goes  crazy. SWISH PAN TO ACE LOOKING ON INTENTLY. On screen, GINGER's hand sneaks a chip from the rack and  subtly moves it towards her purse.
Sound in: GINGER slips the chip quietly into her bag.
(Off-screen) Let's go. This is for Ginger. Come  on. This is for Ginger. The HIGH ROLLER notices GINGER's hand on her purse. She  pretends to have taken out her lipstick.
Let me have a hundred on the hard  ten. Thank you.
Hard ten. One hundred.
ACE continues to look at the monitor. SHERBERT and a secu man seated at a video console also look on.

A craps stick pushes some dice towards GINGER. She rolls  again, only this time she craps out. Gamblers groan, then applaud her. She's made so much money for the table that winners toss chips in her direction.
I'm sorry.
Oh, I'm sorry. I'm sorry. (To the table) Thank you very much. Thank you very  much. ACE and two casino execs are now on the floor watching he
Thank you, sir, I appreciate that.  Everybody, thanks. Gives some chips  as tips to the dealer and box man.  Thanks. Take care, Steve. Take chances  and drive fast.
Ginger, honey.
Thank you very much, now.
Ginger, honey, this is for you love.  Thanks for your time. She turns to the HIGH ROLLER, who is handing her a thin s of chips worth about $2,000.
(Chuckles) Come on.
What's the matter?
What do you mean, 'What's the matter?'  I made a lot of money for you. I  want my cut.
What money? I've seen you stealing  from me.
What money?  Look at this stack of  chips. Don't give me that shit. I  want my end.
Ginger, I've been watching you all  night. You've been stealing from me.
Don't give me that shit. I want my  money.
That bag's full of fuckin' chips you
(Interrupts) What do you mean 'stole'? I didn't  steal anything from you. ACE watches the argument heat up.
Get lost, Ginger! Get lost!
Get lost?
Yes.
Get lost?
Yes. GINGER knocks the chip rack out of his hands.
Well, how 'bout that?

Come on! (He bends down to  pick them up.) Gamblers and dealers shout and yell. She picks up another rack of chips and tosses them into the air, then another, and another. Chips fly all over the casino. Everyone star diving for chips. Dealers. Players. Security guards.   Waitresses. Pit bosses. Bedlam. ACE and the two execs with him are the only ones not divi for chips. He looks at GINGER. She looks at him. FREEZE FRAME ON GINGER. Slow motion: GINGER smiles at ACE and walks off.
What a move. I fell in love right  there.
GINGER and ACE are seated on a banquette. Close up of his hand attaching a diamond and ruby pin to her dress. Tilt to GINGER's smiling face beaming at ACE.
But in Vegas, for a girl like Ginger,  love costs money. They kiss.
I'm going to go powder my nose. (ACE hands GINGER a  single $50 bill. She  smiles coyly. He  hands her another  fifty.)
Ginger's mission in life was money.
I'll be right back.
(from following scene) See you, Ginger.
GINGER waves goodbye to the DOORMAN and walks towards two VALET PARKERS who greet her warmly. She gets a bottle of  pills from one of them and slips some cash into his hand return.
Okay, thank you for asking.
She was a queen around the casino.  She brought in high rollers and helped  them spread around a lot of money.
(To VALET PARKERS) Hello.
Hey, Ginger, how you doin'?
Great. (Handing the VALET  some money.) And I have something for you. You  got me covered? The VALET PARKER places a vial of pills in her hand.
Yes. Something for you, there.
And you do. Thank you very much.
Take care of yourself.
GINGER hands the pills to HIGH ROLLER #2 in his hotel  bathroom, where he is washing his face and trying to ener himself.
I got some lucky pills for you, honey.
Oh, yeah?

Who didn't want Ginger? She was one  of the best-known, best-liked and  most respected hustlers in town.   Smart hustlers like her could keep a  guy awake for two or three days before  sending him home broke to the little  woman and his bank examiners.
GINGER comes back from the ladies room. She kisses ACE.
Any change?
(Chuckles) I hit a few... uh, games on the way  back.
That was all bullshit. She just  pocketed the cash.
GINGER converts her chips into a pile of $100 bills.
(To CASHIER) How you doin' tonight?
Good. How are you?
(Sighing) Oh, beat.
Ginger had the hustler's code.
Okay.
Take one for you.
(While she counts out  the cash) Thank you.
She knew how to take care of people.  And that's what Vegas was all about.
(As she pushes a stack  of $100 bills across  the counter) Sixty-eight hundred.
Thanks She picks up the cash.
You're welcome.
It's Kickback City.
You have a good night.
Thank you. You too. Close-up of GINGER folding a $100 bill and placing it in palm. She slips the folded bill deftly into the palm of a floor manager.
She took care of the dealers...
Hey, Mitch.
...pit bosses, floor managers.
Thank you.
But mostly...
GINGER, on her way out of the casino, passes a folded $10 bill to a smiling older SHIFT BOSS.
...she took care of the valet parkers,  the guys who could get you anything  and take care of anything.
Thanks a lot.
Thank you, Ginger.
GINGER exits and gets into her car, slipping a VALET PARK a $100 bill.
Ginger took care of the parkers  because they took care of the security  guards, who took care of the metro  cops, who let her operate.
Thank you, Ginger.
(Getting into her car) I need that stuff tonight.
No problem.
You're a doll.
The valet parking job was such a  money-maker that they had to pay off  the hotel manager just to get the  concession.
GINGER enters the room with $25,000 in her hands. She tap LESTER DIAMOND's leg with it and he turns to her.
But one thing I could never  understand, was that she could have  everything under control, except for  her old pimp boyfriend, Lester  Diamond.

Look, Gin, you know I got other people  in this. I got partners. But I want  you to understand that I am lookin'  out for you in this thing.  Okay?   You're going to get yours back...    and you're gonna get it back first.  Okay?
All right.
Okay?
Yeah.
Where are you goin'? Where are you?  You're in that place. Where are you?
I'm here.
No, you're not. Where are you? Where  are you?
I'm always here for you.
You are.
I am. He hastily kisses GINGER and slips out the door.
The Ginger I knew wouldn't even look  at this creep.
Good luck.
Yeah.
He was a moocher, a card cheat, a  country-club golf hustler. A  scumbag... chasing dentists for a  few bucks.
Careful. GINGER looks out of the window and sees LESTER get into a convertible and drive off.

I mean, the guy was always broke, he  always had a story. And somehow, she  could never turn him down. The way  Ginger saw it, I guess, was that  Lester was just an unlucky guy.  Somebody had to take care of him.
NICKY, his wife JENNIFER, with a beehive hairdo, and thei eight-year-old son LITTLE NICKY, are detained while their luggage is searched by a customs agent.
But nobody had to take care of Nicky.
(To customs agent) You find any cash in there, we'll  whack it up with you.
I mean, he took care of himself only  too well. And that's why every badge  back home wanted to nail him.
(To customs agent) Excuse me, but I folded these things  beautifully and I would appreciate a  little respect. Jesus Christ!
Don't look at me, pal. I gotta live  with her. We see MARINO waiting for NICKY outside the customs area. Two COPS push past him.
Even after a little vacation, they  hassled him at the airport.
(To MARINO) Excuse me.
I mean, Frank Marino was there to  meet him, but so were the cops. This  time they wanted to pinch him for  some diamond burglary in Antwerp. CAMERA DOLLIES IN ON JENNIFER'S BEEHIVE.
Oh, yes. Will you help me fold these,  please?
They were ready to blame him for  anything, no matter where it happened.
NICKY, JENNIFER, LITTLE NICKY and MARINO walk in.
(To LITTLE NICKY) You go and put your things away.
And they were usually right. NICKY, JENNIFER and MARINO are gathered around the kitche table. JENNIFER leans over and starts to shake her hair.
Whoa, whoa, whoa.
Hold it, hold it. Here. NICKY places a red towel down on the table. JENNIFER lean over again, tugs and shakes her hair until diamonds begin fall out of her beehive.
Because Nicky enjoyed being a  gangster, and he didn't give a damn  who knew it.
Come on. There we go. Look at that.  Beautiful. Diamonds fall on the red towel in slow motion.
I mean, that's what worried me, 'cause  it turns out Nicky was about to be  sent to Vegas.
All right, we're clear.
There's more!
I think that's it.
There's more! There's a couple stuck  in there. I know there's more.
God, I'm telling you, they're out!
Come on, damn it. Don't get so  defensive. It could be stuck in your  hair, you know. NICKY grasps JENNIFER's hair.
Look, there aren't... (A diamond falls out  of her beehive.) There aren't but...
Oh, there aren't? (Showing her the  diamond.) What's that? (Slaps her.) Huh? What's that. (FRANK chuckles.) There's no more. Thanks, hon.
I couldn't wait to get my hands on  Vegas. But the bosses didn't send me  out there to have a good time.

location: SAN MARINO ITALIAN GROCERY/BACK ROOM, KANSAS CITY

text: Mob bosses FORLANO, CAPELLI, GAGGI, BORELLI and PISCANO s around the back room table eating and talking as in the  opening vignette.
They sent me out there to make sure  that nobody fucked with Ace and...
ACE opens the door to NICKY and JENNIFER.
...nobody interfered with the fuckin'  skim.
(Opening door) Hey.
Hey, how you doin'? (Kisses ACE.)
Hey. Hey, Sammy, how are you? JENNIFER and NICKY take in ACE's spectacular Vegas-style  penthouse.
(Whispering) Wow.
Boy, look at this place, huh?
Incredible.
All right.
Welcome to Vegas.
Okay, Sammy.
Somethin', huh?
Yeah.
(Calling her over) Ginger. GINGER emerges from the bedroom. NICKY and JENNIFER are b stunned by her beauty.
(To ACE) Holy shit, what've you been doin'  out here?
Honey, come here. She walks to them
This is Jennifer and Nick. They're  dear friends of mine.
(Shaking hands) Good to meet you.
Hi, Jennifer.
Pleasure. (Grasping GINGER's  hand and kissing it.) Very nice to meet you.
Hi, how are you?
Okay, Sammy.
ACE and NICKY are driving through town, the neon lights o Vegas reflected in the windshield.
After we ate, we left Jennifer and  Ginger alone and we took a ride to  talk. And then... he hit me with it.
What do you think about me movin'  out here? (ACE looks away.) What's the matter? You got a problem  with that?
No, of course not.
(Playfully) You mean, I have your permission?

Sure, you have my permission. But I -  I just gotta tell you it's no joke  out here. It's no joke, you know?   You gotta keep a low profile. It's  not like back home. Right off the  bat, they don't like guys like us.  And this sheriff's a real cowboy.  Even the coppers aren't afraid to  bury people out in the desert here.

I don't care. I want to get away  from back home for a while. I'm tired  of that shit back there. (Referring to the  Vegas lights.) Look at this place. It's made of  money. You know what the best part  is? Nobody's gonna know what we're  doin'! There's nobody here to see  us! Everybody's back home.
Nick, I gotta tell you, I got pinched  twice for no reason. You really gotta  be careful. I'm running a licensed  place. Everything's legit.
Don't worry about it. I'm not gonna  do anything. What am I gonna do?   I'm especially not gonna involve you  in anything. ACE gives NICKY a look.
NICKY and MARINO pull up in their car and get out.
Ace saw Vegas one way.
You call this guy and tell him I'm  comin'?
Of course. They walk into the sportsbook, past numerous bar patrons gamblers to TONY, the bookie at a betting counter.

But I saw it another. I saw it as  untouched. I mean, they had bookies,  pimps and drug dealers I could shake  down. Who the fuck were they gonna  run to?  So, I started getting  everybody in line. Best of all, for  the first time in my life, I figured  out a way not to lose.

Yeah, he had a fool-proof scheme,  all right. It wasn't very scientific  but it worked. When he won, he  collected. When he lost, he told the  bookies to go fuck themselves. What  were they gonna do? Muscle Nicky? (Chuckles.) Nicky was the muscle. NICKY grabs TONY by the back of his neck.
Tony.
Hey.
How you doin'?
How you doin'?
All right, yeah. You got that thing  for me?
What thing? Oh, Nicky... I thought  you was layin'.
I was layin'? No, no, I'm taking it.  I was takin' it.
You sure?
I'm positive.
Well, I'm a little confused here.
You're a little confused?
Yeah.

(Pointing to a window,  above a counter with  a tiny opening to  talk through) Maybe if I stick your fuckin' face  through this window over here like,  you know, you'll - you'll get  unconfused. Give me the fuckin' money! TONY takes some money out of his coat pocket.
(Groaning) I'm sorry, Nicky. I didn't mean  anything by it.
Yeah, I know, that's why you had it  ready. You thought I was fuckin'  layin' it?! He smacks the bookie on the head with the wad of money.
(Gasps) My fuckin' head.
Your fuckin' head, huh? Don't fuck  around, Tony.
(Pointing to TONY) Smarten up.
(Walking out) You jag-off.
(From following scene) And now...
NICKY and JENNIFER stand in the background with other par listening to a NUN school teacher. LITTLE NICKY and other youngsters are seated at small children's desks.
...Nicholas Santoro will come up and  tell us about our first president.
(Stepping up in front  of the class to begin  a speech) George Washington was born in a...
But still, it was nice and quiet for  a while. Ginger and I presented Nicky  and Jennifer all over town, like  regular Ozzie and Harriets.
...typical Virginia farmhouse.
NICKY and DETECTIVE BOB JOHNSON are coaching their sons.  JOHNSON pats LITTLE NICKY on the back and with encouragin words sends him running on to the field.
(To LITTLE NICKY) Beautiful. You got a beautiful swing.
Ace got my son, little Nicky, involved  with Little League, and it was great.
Now, I want you to get out there and  get me singles and doubles, okay?   'Cause that's what's gonna win this  game.
Turned out to be one of the other  coaches was a fuckin'...
Now go out there and show your dad  what you can do.
...metro intelligence cop. But it  didn't matter. I mean, it was all  about the kids, you know.
You know, he's gotta realize  everything can't be a home run that  he does.
Yeah, well, that's exactly what I  keep tellin' him, but that's the  kind of kid he is ever since he's  born.
It's instinctive, you know.
He tries to do everything... LITTLE NICKY hits the ball, NICKY and DETECTIVE JOHNSON  applaud.
Ohh!
And, Nicky being Nicky, he made his  presence known.
NICKY saunters through the casino and up to EDDY and JERR two well-dressed hoods who are signing papers at the cash credit window near ACE and SHERBERT.
Especially at the casino, where he  definitely did not work, people got  the message.

Me? That's why the bosses sent me  out here. They wanted me to make  sure none of the other crews robbed  the joint. Like these two fuckin'  balloon-heads over here [EDDY and  JERRY]. They were gonna try and bang  us out of two hundred fuckin' grand? (Chuckling.) Yeah, right, I'm sure.
(Shakes NICKY's hand) Hey, Nicky. How are you?
Hey, Eddy.
Hey, Nicky, how are you? What are  you doin' here?
I'm over here now.
(In unison) You're over here?
You're over here?
Yeah, I'm over here with him. SWISH PAN TO ACE WITH SHERBERT OFF TO THE SIDE.
Oh.
Oh.
We're waiting on Carmine.
Yeah, we're lookin' for Carmine.
Carmine? He was here before. I saw  him. He had a suitcase and everything,  and then he left.
Carmine left?
Uh-huh.
Carmine left?
He's gone?
He's not here?
Carmine's gone.
I think, you know, maybe he went  across the street or somewhere else  or somethin'. I don't know.
Well, listen, uh... Good luck with  the joint, huh? (Shakes hands with
Oh, thanks, Eddy.
(Shakes NICKY's hand) Yeah, lots of luck. Lots of luck.
Hey, great, Jerry. They walk away.
Good luck to you too.
(To NICKY from behind  the cage) Hey, they forgot to sign their papers.
What?
They forgot to sign their papers.
Yeah, they don't need those anymore. He looks over to ACE and SHERBERT. NICKY smiles.
Out of respect, guys from other crews  got away with a warning. ACE taking a drag off his cigarette, nods an 'okay'.
Everybody else: watch out.
A blackjack WINNER, who looks like a school teacher, with over $100,000 in chips before him has gathered a crowd.

Like these yokels here who never  heard of Nicky or the bosses back  home, 'cause they're the morons who  give you the most trouble. Even after  we'd catch 'em, they'd try sneakin'  back with beards and wigs and fake  noses. ACE and SHERBERT walk up to watch the WINNER who is playi all six hands at the blackjack table.

You can spot these assholes by  watching the way they bet. Like this  guy. He's bettin' lavender chips at  five hundred each with only one little  problem. He's always guessed right.   If he wasn't so fuckin' greedy, he'd  have been tougher to spot. But in  the end, they're all greedy. ACE walks around the WINNER's table, past the crowd, to t pit. Behind him are more blackjack tables, dealers and  players. ACE bends down and ties his shoelace.

I saw that the dealer was weak, but  he wasn't in on it. The DEALER's hands lift the corner of his hole card a hal an inch to determine the casino's hand against the WINNER The slightly exposed hole card is a six of clubs.
He just wasn't protecting his hand.  He was lifting his hole card way to  high.

head_text.subj: THE CARD, PAST A PIT BOS
THE SIGNALER IS SLUMPED DOWN IN HIS SEAT, TOSSING DOWN SO
CARDS AND SNEAKING LOOKS AT THE DEALER'S HAND AT THE WINN

text: Now, here's this guy... OVERHEAD PAN FROM THE SIGNALER SLUMPED IN HIS SEAT.
...reading the dealer's hole card... PAN CONTINUES PAST ACE TO REVEAL THE WINNER'S TABLE.
...and signaling his buddy [the  WINNER] at this table.

head_text.subj: OVERHEAD DOLLY IN ON SIGNALER WHO APPEARS TO BE NERVOUSLY

text: We see through his trousers, that he is tapping a copper  transmitter with a battery pack attached. Back at the WINNER's table we see inside his pant leg whe a device strapped to his leg is receiving the impulse sig buzz - buzz - buzz - from the SIGNALER.
And that's just what these hustlers  look for. They cruise from casino to  casino, lookin' for weak dealers the  way lions look for weak antelope. ACE starts to get up.
(From following scene) Operator?
ACE is on the house phone right near the SIGNALER's table
This is Mr R. Get me Armstrong and  Friday over at pit two right away. He hangs up, and fixes his tie in the mirrored panel abov the phone.

head_text.subj: OVERHEAD VIEW OF THE SIGNALER'S TABLE. VARIOUS SECURITY G
SLOWLY BEGIN TO GATHER AROUND IT.

text: ACE, waiting, lights a cigarette. ARMSTRONG joins ACE. Th look towards the SIGNALER's table.
(To ARMSTRONG) BJ nineteen, second base, the beard  [Blackjack table number 19, second  position, man with the beard]

(Picks up the phone  again.) Operator... I need Mr Happy, loud. On ACE's signal, WAITRESSES, one carrying a cake with a  sparkling candle, start singing 'Happy Birthday', attract the crowd's attention.

(In unison) Happy Birthday to you. Happy Birthday  to you. Happy Birthday, dear Jeff.  Happy Birthday to you. Gamblers cheer and applaud. ACE nods and ARMSTRONG lets a long metal object drop out  from under his jacket sleeve and moves in close behind th SIGNALER, as though looking at the game. He presses the object - a cattle prod - under the SIGNALE arm near his heart. The SIGNALER instantly goes into  convulsions, falling to the floor gasping and groaning.  Several SECURITY GUARDS grab the SIGNALER as he falls.   ARMSTRONG walks away.
Man down! The WINNER sees what happened to his partner.
Notify medical! We got a cardiac  arrest here!
He's fine, folks. Just give us some  room, please! ACE watches the scene. The guards lift the stunned SIGNAL to his feet and help him away from the table. Play is  immediately resumed.
Watch it now. The WINNER hurriedly places his chips into racks.
Stand back!
They never know what hit them. And  if and when... SECURITY GUARDS drag the SIGNALER out.
...they do find out they just got  zapped by a cattle prod... SHERBERT follows the WINNER as he rushes away.
...they wish they really did have a  heart attack. ACE exits behind the GUARDS and the SIGNALER.
A grim, windowless utility room with tools on racks along the walls, some plain wooden chairs, and a workbench tabl
Turns out this guy and his fuckin'  pals, they were knockin' this place  dead for years.
He's got a wire on him. The SIGNALER is roughly shoved into the room. A SECURITY  GUARD tears his trousers down revealing the signaling dev strapped to his leg.
Hey, hey, what are you doin', man?
(Exposing the device) There it is! On the table!
Cheater's justice! The SIGNALER is slammed down face first on the bench and two GUARDS spread his arms out on the table.
(In pain) Oh, God! Oh! Another GUARD starts up a power saw and approaches the  SIGNALER who is now pinned to the table. He starts to scr
Hey, no! No! No! ACE walks toward the table, gesturing for the GUARD to tu off the saw.
We had to make an example of these  pricks that the party was over.
(To relieved SIGNALER) I'm just curious. I saw you shuffling  your checks with your right hand.  Can you do that with both hands?
No.
Can't do it with both hands?
No, Sir.
Can you do it with your left hand?
Well, I... I never tried.
So, you're a righty?
Ye-yeah. ACE nods to one of the GUARDS. Instantly a large rubber m smashes onto the man's right hand four times to the sound screams. ACE watches.
Now, you're gonna have to learn with  your left hand.
God! (He moans and sits  back.)
(From following scene) It's a hundred...
The WINNER has been standing outside the cashier's cage  waiting for his $110,000 in chips to be cashed. SHERBERT  walks up behind him.
...a hundred ten.
Yes, it is.
I think.
Yes.
Okay.
Hiya. That's a lot of money to be  counting out in public.
Yeah.
(To CASHIER) Why don't I take him over to the  office and verify it, huh?
Yes.
A little privacy. And, by the way,  send over a... nice bottle of  champagne on ice, huh?
Sure will.
Real special.  Somethin'... (To WINNER.) By the way...  I'm Billy Sherbert,  your casino manager. He shakes hands with the WINNER.
Hi.
Having a good time? SHERBERT leads him away from the cage.
Yes, uh...
You'll want to count the money in  privacy. You know, you don't need...
Uh, I have a plane to catch to  Cleveland...  Can I get my winnings?
The WINNER is pushed through the door by two GUARDS follo by SHERBERT and sees his pal moaning in pain and holding broken hand.
Look what they did to my hand, man!
(Walks over to the
All right, I'm gonna give you a  choice. You can either have the money  and the hammer or you can walk out  of here. You can't have both. What  do you want? SHERBERT stands next to the WINNER
I just wanna get out of here.
And don't forget to tell your friends  what happens if they fuck around in  here. You understand?
I'm sorry. I made a bad mistake.

You're fuckin' right, you made a bad  mistake. 'Cause if you come back  here - we catch either one of you -  we're gonna break your fuckin' heads  and you won't walk out of here. You  see that fuckin' saw?  We're gonna  use it. You don't fuck around in  this place. You got it?
Yeah.
Get out of here.
Thank you. The GUARDS usher the WINNER out of the room.
(To the GUARDS,  referring to the
Throw him out in the alley.  And  just tell the cops he got hit by a  car.
ACE and GINGER are alone in the living room. The apartmen looks out on the glittering neon signs of the Strip.

Within no time, everything was set  in place. We got rid of the freelance  scamsters. The per was way up.  The  gods were happy, or as happy as the  gods can ever be.  And I, I decided  to complicate my life. For a guy who  likes sure things, I was about to  bet the rest of my life on a real  longshot.
We're not getting any younger. Don't  you think it's time? Aren't you  gettin' tired of all this shit?  Bangin' around, hustlin' around?
What, are you trying to handicap me?
I'm gonna do you one better. I'm  trying to marry you. You want to  marry me? (GINGER looks doubtful.) I'm serious. I mean, I - I want to  settle down. I want a family.
(Sighs, laughing) You got the wrong girl, Sam.
I know I'd be a good father. I know  you'd be a good mother.
You don't know me. What, you've known  me, two, three months. What do you  know?

I'm forty-three years old. I don't  want to wait. I know you well enough  to know that I really love you very  much.  And I can't think of anybody  better to be with. And I don't feel  like waiting anymore.
You know a lot of happily married  people, Sam? 'Cause I don't.
Yeah, I know all that.
I care about you, a - But I just  don't have those kind of feelings  for you. I'm sorry. I'm not in love  with you.
(Brushing cigarette  ash off his dressing  gown) I - I - I...
Understand? (Pause) I'm sorry.

No, I - I... mean...  that can grow  as I - as long as there's a mutual  respect... that kind of thing can  grow. I'm realistic. I can accept  that. But, you know, what is...   What is love anyway?  It's a... it's  a mutual respect. It's - it's a  devotion. It's a... it's a caring  from one person to another. And if  we could set up some kind of  foundation...  based on that mutual  respect...  I feel that eventually  you would care enough about me...  that I could live with that.
If it doesn't work out. You know, if  it doesn't play out, then what happens  to me?

You know I'm doin' well now. And I'm  gonna do even better. And so, whatever  happens, if it doesn't work out  between us, I'm gonna make sure you're  okay for the rest of your life. And  if there are kids, especially, you  know, I'll take care of you better  than you'd ever imagine.
(Interrupts) What're you... what're you pitching  me, here?
Just what I said. You'll be set up  for the rest of your life. That I  can promise you. (Pause) Want to take a chance? She looks at him. ACE is holding her hand tightly.

ACE and GINGER are seated at a banquet table with various guests, drinking champagne. AMY, their six-month-old chil is in a cradle. NICKY and JENNIFER are hovering around th baby with LITTLE NICKY and are blissfully happy. It is an elegant affair.  City Officials, politicians and gaming  officials are there, plus, SHERBERT and Ace's boss, PHILI GREEN. A photographer takes pictures of the guests.
When I married Ginger I knew all the  stories, but I didn't give a fuck.  'I'm Sam Rothstein,' I said. 'I can  change her.'

It was typical Ace. He invited the  biggest people in town and he knew  they'd show. Because he knew they  all wanted somethin' from him.  With  Ace, nobody ever got a free ride.  Even Ginger. With her - We see AMY in the cradle.

- he still covered his bets. They  had to have the baby first, before  they got married. Even made Jennie  and me watch Amy for a few days when  they went on their honeymoon. But I  didn't mind, we loved the kid.

head_text.subj: IN SLOW MOTION CAMERA MOVES IN ON ACE AND GINGER, STANDIN
NEXT TO A LARGE WEDDING CAKE. THEY ARE KISSING. NICKY,
SHERBERT AND OTHER GUESTS LOOK ON.
BRIDE AND GROOM FIGURINES ON THE CAKE.

text: LESTER's and GINGER's telephone conversation is heard in  voice-over this scene.

(Over telephone) Can you feel my eyes on you? Can you  feel me look into your heart?  Can  you feel me in the pit of your  stomach? Can you feel me in you? In  your heart? We see a wide view of the elaborate wedding, guests mill  about the banquet hall.
Don't make me come there. Answer me.
(Over telephone,  sobbing) I love you.
LESTER DIAMOND is talking on the phone softly, cutting up cocaine on a piece of glass.
(Into telephone) Bub-ut, baby, do you know that I  love you too?
(Over telephone) No, Lester.
(Into telephone) Do you know that?
(Over telephone) Yeah. This is the best thing I can  do for my life right now.
(Into telephone) That's right.
GINGER is sitting alone on the phone. She's crying.
(Over telephone) So, it's gonna be okay, isn't it?
(Sobbing, into  telephone) Promise?
(Over telephone) God... I wish you...
There is a beautiful scantily dressed blonde girl in the  apartment with him. She bends down to the table in front him, snorts some cocaine, then walks away.
(Into telephone) ...all the luck in the world.
(Over telephone) You do?

(Into telephone) Yeah, I do. I mean, it's - it's the -  it's the best thing you can do right  now. I mean this. And you'll have  real security.  Sweetheart... you're  gonna be situated just right in Vegas.
ACE enters from the ballroom and sees GINGER on the phone He walks towards her, listening to her conversation.

(Over telephone) Come on, this is great for us. You  know I'm gonna be here for you. I  ain't going no place. Huh?  I'm  lookin' at you right now. I'm seein'  you for the very first time, right  this minute. I'm seein' you, and I  can feel my heart click. I see you  fourteen years old. I see you the  first second I ever saw you. I see  you, long-legged little colt - GINGER notices ACE behind her.
- with stupid braces on your teeth.
(Into telephone,  sniffing, trying to  cut him off) Okay, then.
(Over telephone) Every time I ever see you, that's  what I see.
(Into telephone) Uh, talk to you later.  Bye. (She hangs up the  phone quickly.)
You all right?
(Drinking some  champagne, wiping  away tears) Yeah.
Why're you crying?
(Laughs) I'm not crying. (Sniffs.) ACE walks up behind GINGER.
Maybe you shouldn't drink so much.
I'm okay. I just - (Sniffs) You just have to understand. I've  been with Lester since I was a kid.  I just wanted to say goodbye. I - I  just...  I don't... I think I have a  right to do that. Okay?
It's all right. That part of your  life is over with. Right?
Yeah.
You're with me now.
Yeah.
Right?
Uh-huh.
You sure?
Yeah. Yeah. They are reflected in a mirror behind the telephone.
Want to go? Let's go back in.
(Sniffs) Okay. ACE's hands pick up a white rose and GINGER's gloves from the desk.
ACE and GINGER drive up to an expensive house which backs to a country-club golf course.
ACE takes GINGER inside. It is fancy and lush.
Oh... Through sliding glass doors, we see a patio and a pool ar
(Sighing) It's great. The living-room has exposed white brick along the walls,  bronze ostrich figurines, a white baby grand piano, and a zebra print rug surrounded by a few couches.
Oh, it's great.
ACE takes GINGER past the bedroom to their huge room-size closet. There are racks and racks of clothes.
(Running into the  closet) Oh! It's all my stuff. Oh, my God. ACE presents her with a long chinchilla coat.
You brought all my stuff. I can - She sees the coat.
Try it on. It's yours. He puts it on her.
(Whispering) You're kidding? My God. What is it?
It's chinchilla.
(Looking at herself  in the mirror) Oh, it's so soft.
It's nice isn't it?
Oh... ACE Kisses her.
No one's ever been so nice to me. They kiss and embrace.
ACE's hand opens a leather case full of gold Bvlgari jewe
(Gasps) Oh, my God.
ACE and GINGER lie on the bed, surrounded by jewelry. GIN is swathed in the chinchilla coat. Ace watches as a trans GINGER tries on gold necklaces, rings, bracelets and earr
So, do you think it's too much if I  wear these in the same day?
You do whatever you want. Do I keep  my promises, or do I keep my promises? ACE kisses GINGER.
You're so wonderful. The jewelry's  not so bad, either.
The only thing is... you shouldn't  keep this in the house. We gotta put  it in a bank.
(Putting on a gold  bracelet) Come on. Can I keep this one in the  house?
Now look, (gently holding her  face, gathering her  total attention) pay attention to me. What I'm gonna tell you is very important.
Okay.
All this stuff doesn't mean anything.  Money, this, doesn't mean anything  without trust. I have to be able to  trust you with my life.
ACE and GINGER get off the Tangiers jet carrying two  suitcases. ACE gives a chauffeur the luggage and follows  GINGER into a brown Rolls Royce.
With over a million in cash and jewels  tucked in a bank in Vegas only for  Ginger, she was secure and happy.
ACE and GINGER walk into the bank lobby carrying the  suitcases.
She loved that shit. But a guy in my  line of work has to have a lot of  pay-off cash around.
There are several safe deposit boxes filled with cash. AC and GINGER are closing a large box so crammed with cash t ACE has to lean on it for the clasp to lock.
Crooked cops and kidnappers, they  don't take checks.
Need a little help with that, Mr  Collins?

So, I put two million in cash in a  Los Angeles bank under the name of  Mr and Mrs Tom Collins. This was  strictly my shakedown and kidnapping  money. ACE and GINGER struggle to push the crammed box into a sl in the wall.

And, since I'd either be in jail or  locked in a closet when I needed the  money the most... The BANK PRESIDENT joins them, and he and ACE simultaneou double-lock the outer safe box door with two separate key after which, ACE gives GINGER his key.
...I gave Ginger the only key to the  cash that could get me back alive.
GINGER is on the other side of a glass wall, signing pape
Now this is just a signature card.
So, once she signs those papers,  she'll be the only person to have  total access to the box?  No one  else, including myself?
That's right. We see GINGER looking at ACE.
That's the way you wanted it, right? ACE nods
(Quietly.) Sam, let me ask you a question. You  must really trust your wife.
(Quietly) Yeah, sure I do. Why?
No, tha-that's good. It's just  unusual. To tell you the truth, so  many of my clients don't.
Well... ACE looks over to GINGER, smiles and winks. She looks bac at him.
JERRY VALE sings to a seated audience. ACE sits alone at table.

With Ginger and the money in place,  I felt covered, and to play it safe  I switched job titles again and made  myself, um, Food and Beverage  Director. This way nobody would bother  me about a license. I mean, Vegas  was like a dream for me. Trouble  was... NICKY is seated at another table with MARINO, peeling off money and giving it to MIKE, a crooked dealer.
...Nicky was dreamin' his own kind  of Vegas.
To begin, I put money out on the  streets, chargin' three points a  week. You know - juice to the fuckin'  dealers.
(To MIKE) Don't make us come lookin' for you.
Oh, you won't have to look for me. I  appreciate it. Thanks, Nicky.
All right, Mike. MIKE gets up from the table.
They were degenerate gamblers, coke  freaks. In no time, I had half the  dealers in the Tangiers in my pocket.   Then...

NICKY is at a table with his gang of card sharks: SLIM, R MOOSH and COWBOY, all secretly signaling each other,  sandbagging a mark. MIKE, the crooked dealer from the pre scene, deals NICKY a winning hand.
...the next thing I did, I started  bustin' out high-stakes poker players.
It was so obvious. I mean, all of  Nicky's half-assed mechanics, they  were real signal happy.
(Scratching his arm) I'm gonna open for five hundred.
Moosh, you open? (Taps his fingers on  some chips before  picking them up.)
Signaling back and forth.
I bet thirty-five hundred. NICKY wiggles a toothpick back and forth in his mouth.
I've been losing for three days  straight, non-stop. Another shark pulls on his ear.
Oh, why're you crying, with three  loaves of bread under your arm? ACE watches their signals with concern.
Nicky thought nobody was watching  him. But he was wrong. We see two undercover gaming agents, looking like tourist sneaking looks at NICKY's table.
And I didn't want any of those agents  near my place.
Four aces, Doc. His hands spread five cards on the table, showing four ac
What do you got?
(Getting up in disgust) Jesus Christ. I can't believe it. COWBOY, the card shark with the cowboy hat, rakes in a la pot toward his side of the table.
If I didn't have bad luck, I wouldn't  have any luck. I'm out of here, you  understand?
I mean, I wished to God Nicky and  his whole crew would just get lost. He walks towards NICKY's table.
What am I gonna do? Go back home and  start a war? ACE leans down to talk to NICKY.
I mean, Nicky's a made guy and I'm  not. I can't do that.
(Whispering in NICKY's  ear) Be careful. Gaming agents are all  over the place.
So, I'm lucky. I'm not allowed to  get lucky in this place?
You been lucky all week. They're  lookin' to nail ya. ACE walks away. NICKY looks over at the gaming agents.
Ace was so fuckin' worried about his  casino, he forgot what we were doin'  out here in the first place.
Security people are pulling apart a husband and wife who fighting. Camera picks up ACE as he passes by them.
A million times I wanted to yell in  his fuckin' ear: 'This is Las Vegas!   We're supposed to be out here robbin',  you dumb fuckin' Heeb.'
Closeup of the COWBOY's white-socked feet with no shoes o poker table.

(To SHERBERT, referring  to COWBOY) I don't give a shit who he's connected  to. Tell him to take his fuckin'  feet off the table. What's he think  this is, a goddamn sawdust joint? SHERBERT approaches COWBOY.
Sir, would you mind taking your feet  off the table and putting your shoes  on, please?
(Sighs) Yeah, I would mind. I'm havin' a bad  night. COWBOY remains the same with his feet on the table.
(Returning to ACE) Fuckin' asshole won't budge.
Call security. ACE approaches COWBOY.
How are you?
Good. How are you?
Good. You want to do me a favor? You  want to take your feet off the table  and put your shoes back on?
Fuck you. ACE walks to nearby SECURITY GUARDS.
(To GUARDS) I want you to exit this guy off the  premises, and I want you to exit him  off his feet and use his head to  open the fuckin' door. Three SECURITY GUARDS approach COWBOY.
Sir, you're gonna have to leave. You  mind accompanying us outside?
Bullshit, I ain't goin' anywhere  with you!
Bullshit, you're out of here, cowboy! SECURITY GUARD #1 knocks his feet off the table, as GUARD #2 and #3 lift him off his seat.
Fuck you! Fuck you!
Yeah?
You know who you're fuckin' with?!  Huh? Do you?!
Now move along.
(Screaming at ACE who  follows him) You fuckin' faggot! Do you know who  you're fuckin' with? The GUARDS carry him out and forcefully shove him towards side exit.
Leave me alone!
Here we go!
(Grunting) You've gotta be kidding me! (Groans.) The GUARDS lift him off his feet and, holding him like a  battering ram, smash his head into the door.
(As COWBOY is thrown  out the door) Sure enough, an hour later, I get  the call.
NICKY is on a public wall-phone talking to ACE. MARINO is staring at the disheveled COWBOY.
(Into telephone) Ace, what happened over there? I  mean, did you know that guy you threw  out was with me?
ACE is on a Tangiers house phone. SHERBERT looks on.
(Into telephone) No, I didn't know that. But you know  what he did?
(Over telephone) No.
NICKY gives COWBOY a look.
(Over telephone) He insulted Billy. And then I walked  over to him politely...
(Into telephone) ...and he tells me to go fuck myself.
(Over telephone) What?
(Into telephone) Then he called me a faggot.
(Over telephone) So what do you think I do? I threw  that cocksucker out.
(Into telephone) What? Ho- (He puts down the  phone; to COWBOY:) Hey, come here. COWBOY walks up to him.
You called my friend a faggot? You  tell him to go fuck himself?
Nicky, I did -
Is that what you did?
I did - I didn't -
Tell him to go fuck himself? You  fuckin' hick!  Fuckin'... NICKY hits him on the head with the phone. COWBOY falls b groaning.
ACE listens to the noise of NICKY roughing up COWBOY.
(Over telephone) ...you big fuckin' hick, you. Come  here. Come here. Get him up. Come  here. ACE LOOKS AT SHERBERT.
(Over telephone) Get up.
(To COWBOY) Come here, come here.
Get up.
You go over there right now and you  apologize. You better hope he lets  you back in.
(Over telephone) If you ever get out of line over  there again, I'll smash your fuckin'  head so hard...
(To COWBOY) ...you won't be able to get that  cowboy hat on. You hear me? Fuckin'  hick. (Into telephone) Sammy, listen...
(Over telephone) ...this guy obviously doesn't know  who he was talkin' to, you understand?  He doesn't...

(Into telephone) ...know that, uh, we're dear friends.  I mean, he's already very sorry.  But, uh, if you could do me a favor  to let him back in, I swear to you  he'll never get out of line again. I  promise you that.
(Into telephone) If he does it again, he's out for  good. I don't care what it is, Nick,  I'm gonna ha- I'll - I'll never let  him in the place again.
(Over telephone) I'm sorry about this. Really.
(Into telephone) All right, Ace?
(Over telephone) Okay.
(Into telephone) Thanks, pal. NICKY hangs up the phone and turns to COWBOY.

You took your boots off? You put  your feet on the table... you shit- kicking, stinky, horse-manure-smellin'  motherfucker you!  You fuck me up  over there, I'll stick you in a hole  in the fuckin' desert! You understand? (Slapping him.) Go over there and apologize. (Kicking the chastened  COWBOY away.) Go! Get the fuck out of -
Nicky, I'm sorry.

A tiger leaps towards the camera, which pans over to two  showgirls and then to ACE's hand holding the key to a Rol Royce. He gives it to JONATHAN and DAVID as reporters rus in to photograph the moment.

You know, Ace could be a very touchy  guy, especially when he got bigger  and bigger in town. Like when he  hired that Jonathon and David and  their tigers away from the Palace by  buildin' them a new stage and then  givin' them a silver Rolls Royce.
ACE and SHERBERT watch as a STAGE MANAGER weighs in the ' Fatale' Showgirls.

But I'll tell you, he knew how to  bring in the crowds. He knew all the  fuckin' angles. He brought over the  whole 'Femme Fatale' show from Paris.  But he forgot how lazy them European  dancin' broads can get. I mean, he  had to weigh 'em in once a week to  make sure they didn't blow up like  fuckin' balloons.
(To SHOWGIRL) You're still eight pounds over. (To MANAGER.) What's the reason for this?
Mr Rothstein, sir, let me put her on  suspension.
Never mind the 'sir'. Never mind the  'sir'.
Well, sir, I was just...
Why is she eight pounds over?
...trying to offer you the respect  that your...
...position...
'Mr Rothstein' is good enough.
Mr Rothstein... well, sometimes,  when you reach that pressure point,  when you put that pressure point on  them, you know, it shows...
She could at least lose half a pound  or a quarter.  Listen...
...and she doesn't always -
...all you do is give me answers.  Just - just give me the right answer.
But, sir. Well, I don't know why. I  guess, maybe, because she's frightened  that if she doesn't lose the weight  she may even get fired.
That's right. She will get fired. In  fact, I want you to send her back to  Paris.
It's always been our policy -
No. Just stop everything. SHERBERT and ACE walk away across a huge stage.
(To ACE) This woman's an institution.
I don't care what she is. She's an  institution, that's the problem.  She's lazy.

ACE standing in a large space surrounded by giant TV scre showing sports events. Around him, long rows of bettors a seated at betting stations, lined up at windows, or wande around at the bar. It's like a NASA control room on launc day.

Hey, I gotta give the guy credit. He  does the most obvious thing. This is  the only town in the country where a  bookie joint is legit, so, why not  take advantage, right?  So... he  took bookie joints off the street  and then opened them up inside the  casino. Well, within a few years, by  doin' all of this, he had every casino  on the Strip trying to copy off him.
Between...
NICKY, with MARINO, punching and kicking a man next to th open door of his luxury car.
...my innovations... The man falls to the ground.
...and Nicky's dedication to his  job... NICKY starts kicking him.
...I soon had the best operation on  the Strip. NICKY lifts an empty trash can and shatters the car's  windshield.
ACE and NICKY are standing on the casino floor near the s machines. Gamblers are milling about behind them.
You better watch yourself. There's a  lot of heat on you already.
Why, somebody's complaining?
I'm - I'm hearin' things from  security. They're all ex-cops. The  Sheriff's lookin' to bust your balls.  They want to put you in the Black  Book.
That Black Book is a bunch of  bullshit. They got two names in there  for the whole country and one of  them is still Al Capone.
Bullshit or no bullshit, they put  you in that book, you're gonna be in  a lot of trouble. You will not be  able to walk into the casino. I'm  tellin' you.
What am I doin' out here? I'm tryin'  to make a livin', that's all.
I'm just tellin' you. Don't say I  didn't warn you.
All right.

Tight on the filaments of a flash bulb as they ignite. TV news crews and still photographers are taking pictures ACE and GINGER surrounded by clusters of celebrities and Vegas power elite, including SHERBERT and GREEN, at a bla tie event.
Mrs Rothstein, look straight ahead.  Very nice. Thank you.
Thank you.
Yes, nice smile.
Just look right at the camera. Hold  that pose. We hear GREEN making a speech over flashing cameras and f frames of himself, SHERBERT, ACE and GINGER.
Considering all of his hard work and  dedication and the new lifeblood he  has instilled in Las Vegas... We now see GREEN at a mike speaking in front of the seate club members.

Sam has established himself as an  indispensable member of the gaming  community. As the head of the Tangiers  Gaming Corporation, it's my pleasure  to welcome Sam Rothstein to the Vegas  Valley Country Club. Members cheer and applaud as GREEN hands ACE a framed  citation. It reads: 'This Certificate of Appreciation. Sa Rothstein. Charitable Foundations of Greater Las Vegas'.  They shake hands for the photographers.
Back home, they would have put me in  jail for what I'm doing. But out  here, they're givin' me awards.
(Into the microphone) It's with great pleasure that I accept  this certificate of appreciation  from the...
A dazzling GINGER moves charmingly about the room chattin up top executives, lawyers, judges, bankers and their wiv ACE, standing with GREEN and an elderly man, watches her  work the room.
Congratulations, sweetheart.
Thank you.
Sam raised more than we've ever raised  before.
He worked so hard.
But my greatest pleasure was watchin'  my wife, Ginger, work the room.
Thank you for everything.
They all loved her. How could you  not live her?
(To COUNTRY-CLUB WOMAN
Hi. Nice to see you.
She could be the most charming woman  you ever saw. People loved to be  around her.
Listen, you've got to bring Amy to  Sasha's birthday party because he'd  love to have her there.
Thanks.
We'll see you three o'clock Saturday.
Thanks. Yes, all right.
Great.
She made everybody feel good. GINGER joins ACE. He smiles proudly.
GINGER and ACE are off alone by a dining-room table, talk intently. A young casino EXECUTIVE interrupts them.
Congratulations, Sam.
(Shaking his hand) Oh, thanks. The flirting EXECUTIVE looks at GINGER.
Hello, Mrs Rothstein.
Hi.
How are you?
Oh. GINGER gives the flirting EXECUTIVE her hand, he kisses i

You're one of the most gorgeous women  I've ever seen. You're a lucky man  Mr Rothstein. ACE watches as GINGER flashes one of her dazzling smiles, but he's not sure whether she's flirting. He looks at the young man and back at his wife.
Thank you. Thanks for that compliment.
He was a young kid from the casino...  nice kid...  bright boy. What balls  on this fuckin' kid! The next day I  fired him. Freeze frame on ACE smiling at GINGER.
GINGER, with two-year-old AMY in a stroller, is seated on bench going through large bank vault boxes containing her jewels.
(To AMY) Hey, do you want to see this one?  Daddy gave me all this jewelry because  he loves me so much. (She places a  gold bracelet on AMY's hand.) Put  your arm in there.
But as much as they loved her...
(To AMY, wearing the  bracelet) Oh, fabulous.
...they didn't know what really moved  her. She holds up a necklace to the light.
Look at this. Look at this.

head_text.subj: CAMERA PULLS AWAY FROM THE DOOR LEADING TO THE VIEWING RO
REVEALING A BANK MANAGER SEATED AT A DESK. WE HEAR GINGER

text: (From the viewing  room) Daddy gave me this pin when we were  dating.
And with Ginger happy, I was able to  concentrate on what I knew best.
ACE is talking to DON WARD.
Loose machines are right back over  there.
What are they doin' way back there?  Bring 'em up here where they belong.   You can't even see 'em over there.
Okay, I'll -
What about the progressives with the  high jackpots? Where are they? These  machines are hidden.
Well...
These are our best machines. They  bring all the action. No wonder the  drop is off.
Yeah, okay.
